posts.cooked: The NegCon, a PlayStation controller designed for Ridge Racer, features a middle section that twists to enable rotation. The 4-directional control stick allows for movement in four primary directions. Beyond its typical support for eight directions, offering more flexibility than intended.

Could you possibly do it for the sake of it? Absolutely. Using it in competition isn’t advisable; the D-pad resolution would be terrible compared to a traditional controller, limiting movement to just the four cardinal directions.  

That is, unless next year’s game is FIRST For Inspiration and Recognition of Science and Technology Chess, presented by Haas and Chess.com, which will also be part of the 2026 Season, alongside Sand from Qualcomm.

posts.name: Brendan Simons, 5406
posts.cooked: We tried this X-Box controller steering knob hack in 2023. The result didn’t noticeably increase performance. Last year, during a competition, we faced challenges with drivers spending excessive time aligning with targets. A discussion about control schemes led us to explore a better interface for swerve drives.
There is no Wii remote available.

posts.name: Pedro Braga
posts.cooked: To be honest, now I kind of want to try driving a good field-oriented swerve combined with an elevator using one of these. It feels like it could be a quite intuitive control scheme. Though pitch might be sufficiently intuitive for an arm, I think the risks of accidentally triggering unintended inputs are too high.

Negcon was THE best racing controller for the PS1, featuring analogue steering and buttons. Most PS1 racing games used it, including all Ridge Racer games, Wipeout 1 & 2, and you could use it for Namco games like Tekken too. Unfortunately, there’s no modern version available now.
